image.altText: A woman sobs as people stand against a sandstone wall at a funeral

items.synopsis: Here in Jerusalem, there's an ominous, almost eerie sense that something big is about to happen. But it is important that a humanitarian catastrophe be avoided. Civilians are civilians — whether Israeli or Palestinian, writes John Lyons.

title.children: On Jerusalem streets, there's an ominous sense that something big is about to happen

image.altText: two firefighters looking at burnt ground

items.synopsis: Residents in five regions, including Greater Sydney, are being told to stay alert ahead of the hot and windy conditions forecast for today. The fire risk is rated as high for much of the rest of the state.

title.children: Schools closed, extreme fire danger warnings issued across NSW as South Coast blaze burns on

image.altText: A group of young poeple

items.synopsis: Patrons will overhear many different languages at this pub in Canberra as a group of polyglots gather.

title.children: The Canberra pub that's become a melting pot of multilingualism

image.altText: Writer, blogger Yang Hengjun

items.synopsis: Pro-democracy activist Yang Hengjun remains behind bars along with other Australians in China — but the release of journalist Cheng Lei gives his supporters fresh hope.

title.children: Cheng Lei has been released but now there are other Australians imprisoned in China to fight for

image.altText: Left: A woman in Shanghai wears a black dress and pink jacket. Right: A woman talks on the phone

items.synopsis: Australian journalist Cheng Lei has returned to Australia and been reunited with her family — more than three years after she was first detained in China. Here's how the story unfolded.

title.children: Accused of 'supplying state secrets', Cheng Lei spent three years in a Chinese prison. Here's how she made it home

image.altText: An illustration of a person's hand placing a ballot paper into a ballot box held by someone else's outstretched hands.

items.synopsis: Follow our live coverage of the Voice to Parliament campaign on Thursday, October 12.

title.children: 4 million Australians have already voted with referendum poll less than 48 hours away

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yagara and Bundjalung elder, Uncle Valentine Brown, attended the Winston Glades polling station near Ipswich, west of Brisbane, on Tuesday. The 73-year-old said when he entered the polling station, official workers told him he wasn't allowed to vote while wearing a Yes shirt, but did not give him an explanation as to why. He was told to go home and change clothes if he wanted to cast his ballot. "We were just going around peacefully, doing our business to vote," Mr Brown said. In a statement, a spokesperson encouraged voters to not wear campaign clothing, as the law states people cannot campaign within 6 metres of a polling station. "If a voter simply wears campaign material (ie a pin or shirt) into the polling place, casts their vote and leaves, it likely won't contravene the act," the AEC spokesperson said. "However, if the voter wears that material into a polling place and is then seen talking with someone inside about it … that could be construed as campaigning."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Indigenous elder turned away from voting centre for wearing Yes shirt

featuredLink.title: Don't wear 'Yes' or 'No' clothing when you vote in the Voice referendum, AEC warns

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We will be bringing you the latest developments on the Voice to Parliament referendum as they happen today. Yesterday, "Father of reconciliation" Pat Dodson gave his National Press Club address, saying that a No result in the referendum would send the country backwards. Twenty-five Australians of the Year signed an open letter urging people around the country to vote Yes. Linda Burney called for Peter Dutton to apologise for his comments about late Northern Territory land rights giant Yunupiŋu. Former MP Pat Farmer completed his 14,000km journey around the country campaigning for the Yes vote. Stay tuned for the latest updates as they unfold today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Welcome to our live coverage

image.altText: A composite image of 1967 and 1999 referendums and 2017 same-sex marriage vote

items.synopsis: Here's what those historic votes can, and can't, tell us about how NSW will vote when asked whether First Nations people should be recognised in the Australian Constitution with a Voice to Parliament.

title.children: Data shows us that demographics, not politics, could sway NSW's vote on The Voice

image.altText: Smoke rising from buildings

items.synopsis: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and a leading opposition figure create a war-time Cabinet to fight Hamas terrorists.

title.children: As air strikes devastate Gaza, Israel forms unity government to oversee war sparked by Hamas attack

image.altText: A blurred car driving on the highway with petrol prices showing behind it

items.synopsis: Oil prices have risen on fears supply from Iran will be cut due to sanctions imposed by the United States. Experts say we could be in for more pain at the pump just before Christmas.

title.children: What does Israel’s war on Hamas mean for petrol prices in Australia?

image.altText: Cortnee Vine kicks the winning penalty against France at the Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: After her iconic penalty shootout goal against France, Sydney FC forward Cortnee Vine wants to shine a light on the A-League Women.

title.children: Matildas penalty hero Cortnee Vine still caught in World Cup whirlwind

image.altText: A man in suit speaks at a conference.

items.synopsis: In a wide-ranging speech delivered in Taiwan's capital, former prime minister Scott Morrison says it is time for a modernisation of the One China policy, as he meets with President Tsai Ing-wen at a forum.

title.children: Morrison argues for 'modernised One China framework' in Taiwan speech

image.altText: Two profile shots of two men who are in politics in NZ.

items.synopsis: The New Zealand election is going to be very close, with at least one party concerned there will be no clear winner and the country will have to vote again.

title.children: Why these two men are refusing to work together after NZ election night

image.altText: Uncle Val and Auntie Rhonda wear yes T-shirts

items.synopsis: An Indigenous elder says he was turned away from voting for the Voice to Parliament because he was wearing a Yes campaign shirt.

title.children: Don't wear 'Yes' or 'No' clothing when you vote in the Voice referendum, AEC warns

image.altText: Two men put ballot papers into a box.

items.synopsis: The crisis in Israel is unlikely to directly shift votes one way or another in the Australian Voice referendum, but it does make it harder for the Yes campaign to be heard at precisely the time it needs to be, writes David Speers.

title.children: With days left for the Voice campaign, it just got harder for Yes and Albanese to break through

image.altText: 3D mosaic of Bennu asteroid

items.synopsis: NASA's first studies on the fragments of the asteroid Bennu are in and they are cause for hope that the samples may contain clues to the foundations of life on Earth.

title.children: NASA finds more carbon than expected in Bennu asteroid sample

image.altText: A couple stand in a caravan surrounded by a workspace and fridge.

items.synopsis: Hundreds of homes were destroyed by floodwater in the Victorian town of Rochester when the Campaspe River burst its banks in October, 2022. Some residents will have to wait another year before they can move back into their homes.

title.children: Rebuild 'another full year' away for couple living in caravan after record flood

image.altText: Tanya Plibersek stands behind Anthony Albanese at a press conference

items.synopsis: The Federal Court has ruled the government can approve coal mines without considering emissions. That's not sustainable in the long run, writes Michael Slezak.

title.children: 'Bitterly disappointed': The federal government's just had a big win against environmentalists in court

image.altText: A man in black suit sits in front of a microphone.

items.synopsis: Russians who fled the country to side with Ukraine should be charged with treason and sent to work in mines, says Vyacheslav Volodin, the chairman of Russia's parliament.

title.children: Russian political leader looks for Gulag-like punishment for those returning who supported Ukraine

image.altText: An Israeli and Australian flag wave among large group of Jewish community

items.synopsis: Thousands of people gather in a cliff-side park in Sydney's east in support of Israel, as NSW Premier Chris Minns and federal Opposition Leader Peter Dutton denounce Hamas "barbarity".

title.children: 'Never tolerated': Minns, Dutton among speakers as thousands gather at Israel vigil in Sydney

image.altText: A middle-aged woman with brown hair stands between two other women with a reflective expression on her face.

items.synopsis: Kylee Pearn's experience dealing with police was positive when she reported she had been sexually abused as a child. Now, she's concerned about police involvement in a review of its handling of child sexual allegations made against a former officer.

title.children: Kylee wants victim-survivor stories to be heard. She fears a review into child sex abuse won't be 'full and thorough'

image.altText: Close up of Shah. He has black hair, a moustache and goatee.

items.synopsis: The PNG government says Australia committed to providing funding to support the refugees there until they were all resettled, but service providers allege they are owed tens of millions of dollars.

title.children: Refugees fear eviction as PNG and Australia clash over 'outstanding invoices'

image.altText: Cal Wilson smiling with a microphone wearing brightly-coloured clothing.

items.synopsis: The Melbourne-based comedian entered the scene when there were few women in the industry. Her legacy lives on through the many women she mentored along the way.

title.children: Comedian Cal Wilson leaves behind a legacy of laughter and generosity

image.altText: Birdsville local Don Rowlands stands outside on a day where the temperature reached 49.3C

items.synopsis: Ranger and Wangkangurru Elder Don Rowlands lived through the first referendum on Indigenous rights. With the vote on the Voice to Parliament approaching, he says it would give Indigenous Australians a seat at the table.

title.children: When Don Rowlands was young, he wasn't paid for his work on cattle stations. That changed after the 1967 referendum

image.altText: A close-up shot of a Proserpine rock-wallaby

items.synopsis: Warren Spicer, 81, dug out a massive dam inside Dryander National Park, home of the Proserpine rock-wallaby that only lives within restricted rainforest areas of the Whitsundays region.

title.children: Man fined $14,000 for dam built in national park, home to endangered wallaby

image.altText: Cracks in paddocks highlight the lack of moisture in North Coast soils.

items.synopsis: With more than 30 per cent of the state in drought, supplementary feeding has begun on Northern Rivers farms, and soil-water index levels are at a 100-year low.

title.children: 'Levels at zero': Soil moisture at record low in Northern Rivers as intense drought spreads

image.altText: A woman in a blue shirts sits beside black cattle eating hay.

items.synopsis: Researchers in regional NSW say cattle that ate the additive had methane emission reductions of up to 99 per cent.

title.children: Dutch cattle feed additive cuts methane emissions massively in Australian research trials

image.altText: Graphic of Google Pay and Apple Pay logos

items.synopsis: Apple and Google will soon be required to comply with rules already imposed on credit cards and EFTPOS transactions, pushing past concerns from Apple it could harm the emerging technology.

title.children: Apple and Google's digital wallets to be brought under payment rules

image.altText: A child has their teeth examined by a dentist.

items.synopsis: Fewer people across Queensland will receive fluoride in drinking water supplies, as another council announces it will axe its program, citing freedom of choice and costs.

title.children: Dentists say fluoride in drinking water keeps costs down, but councils continue to axe programs

image.altText: A man with a beard and a hat with the colours of the Aboriginal flag on its band.

items.synopsis: Prominent Indigenous leader and politician Pat Dodson says a No result in the Voice to Parliament referendum would send the country backwards.

title.children: 'Father of reconcilliation' Pat Dodson says a No result in Voice referendum would send the country 'backwards'

image.altText: A large brown bear wading through shallow water near a river bank.

items.synopsis: A female brown bear named Grazer is voted the winner of Alaska's popular Fat Bear Week poll.

title.children: Fat Bear Week title awarded to female who gained weight during 'single girl summer'
